Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Deep inferior epigastric artery perforator (DIEP) flap reconstruction has become a well-established procedure for breast reconstruction. While vascular compromise is not common, venous congestion is the most commonly reported cause of such compromise, and of those that may require re-exploration, insufficient venous drainage is the most common cause. In such cases, flap salvage may require establishment of a secondary venous outflow source. In a standard unilateral breast reconstruction with a DIEP flap, zone IV is discarded, with the intra-flap segment of the superficial inferior epigastric vein (SIEV) unused. We describe the novel approach of harvesting the SIEV within zone IV and banking within the breast pocket near the contralateral superficial vein should it be required for further salvage surgery. Our approach involves harvest of the SIEV on a side table (which allows simultaneous operating), flushing the graft with heparinized saline, and tagging the proximal end with an 8/0 nylon suture. This vein graft is then transferred and banked at the breast recipient site, near the flap vein where it is likely to be required. This simple step prevents further morbidity of a secondary donor site and reduces operative time should re-exploration be required.
Level of Evidence: Level V, therapeutic study

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Deep inferior epigastric artery perforator (DIEP) flap reconstruction has become a well-established procedure for breast reconstruction. While vascular compromise is not common, venous congestion is the most commonly reported cause of such compromise, and of those that may require re-exploration, insufficient venous drainage is the most common cause. In such cases, flap salvage may require establishment of a secondary venous outflow source. Some authors utilize a secondary venous outflow source as a primary manoeuvre, while others use a “wait-and-see” approach, rather than prophylactically performing a secondary venous outflow, given that venous congestion occurs in less than 5–10 % of cases (the approach that we employ) [1–5].

Varying means augmenting or supercharging the venous drainage of congested or compromised flaps that have been described. The methods used to augment this venous drainage have included the use of additional venae comitantes of the ipsilateral DIEA [6], the venae comitantes of the contralateral DIEA [7], through the ipsilateral superficial inferior epigastric vein (SIEV) [8, 9], and the contralateral SIEV [10]. While all of these options are suitable, and may be individualized, many of these often require a vein graft to reach recipient vessels.

In a standard unilateral breast reconstruction with a DIEP flap, zone IV is discarded, with the intra-flap segment of the SIEV unused. We describe the novel approach of harvesting the SIEV within zone IV and banking within the breast pocket near the contralateral superficial vein should it be required for further salvage surgery.

Section2.Heading: Surgical technique
Section2.Para:
Our approach involves harvest of the SIEV on a side table (which allows simultaneous operating), flushing the graft with heparinized saline, and tagging the proximal end with an 8/0 nylon suture (see Fig. 1). This vein graft is then transferred and banked at the breast recipient site, near the flap vein where it is likely to be required (see Fig. 2). Our approach to secondary venous drainage for flap salvage begins with choice of recipient vessel, typically involving the use of a vein in the axilla, usually of the subscapular system: the serratus branch of the thoracodorsal vein, a thoracodorsal vein, or lateral thoracic vein. Other options include using an internal mammary vein or a cephalic turn-down. Both options can be useful, although there is some contention in the literature [11]. Regardless of recipient choice, we utilize a superficial inferior epigastric vein stump from the flap with a vein graft. The approach described herein offers ready availability of this graft.

Section2.Heading: Representative case
Section2.Para: We have performed this manoeuvre in 20 cases to date, and in this series, we encountered a single case in which the graft was required. In this case, flap raise entailed a single-perforator DIEP flap, in which the flap displayed signs of global venous congestion after anastomosis of the primary pedicle to the thoracodorsal vessels. A decision to augment venous drainage to facilitate flap salvage was made, and the need for a vein graft to the ipsilateral SIEV was identified (no photographs available).

As such, the contralateral SIEV graft was utilized as a vein graft, harvested from the flap recipient site. Harvest time was several seconds, as preparation had been performed previously, and no additional donor sites required. Graft length available was 15 cm. Anastomosis to the ipsilateral (congested) SIEV and an internal mammary artery perforator were thus performed. The congestion was rapidly alleviated, and the flap inset and managed in a routine manner thereafter. A postoperative photograph 24 h after salvage is shown in Fig. 3. There have been no complications from the harvest or use of the described technique in any cases, and this simple step prevents further morbidity of a secondary donor site and reduces operative time should re-exploration be required.

Section1.Heading: Discussion
Section1.Para: The current report describes a straightforward operative step which offers the rapid availability of vein graft in the setting of re-exploration for venous congestion or compromise. The technique is readily employed routinely, requiring little additional operative time and no donor morbidity. This can further reduce morbidity of a secondary donor site and reduce operative time should re-exploration be required.

The implications of inadequate venous drainage of DIEA perforator flaps are critical to operative success, with the potential for partial or complete flap loss. While identification of venous compromise clinically is straightforward for most reconstructive surgeons, understanding the cause for venous compromise in individual cases is difficult to predict. Identification of the features of draining veins that optimize venous drainage, through both superficial and deep venous systems, can be selected preoperatively for inclusion in the flap. Previous anatomical studies have sought to identify these features in cadaveric and clinical studies through various means: assessing the direction of venous flow past valves [12–16], demonstrating that the direction of venous flow is preferentially from the superficial venous system to the deep venous system, through a series of perforating veins. The size of venous perforators has also been highlighted as a significant contributing factor to venous congestion, with cases highlighting no suitable perforating veins in an entire hemiabdominal wall, proposing that venous compromise is “probably due to the sacrifice of a critical number of venous perforators” [12]. This hypothesis has been confirmed experimentally, showing that the calibre of perforating veins is the limiting factor to venous drainage [17, 18], and has been confirmed also in a clinical study of the DIEA perforator flap [9].

In addition to perforator diameter and flow, the degree of midline crossover by the SIEV has been implicated as a cause for flap venous congestion [16, 19]. While a single perforator is widely used to drain the entire flap, venous drainage is essential through communication with veins of each side of the abdominal wall. Blondeel et al. [16] identified a lack of midline crossover by the SIEV in 36 % of cases dissected, while Schaverien et al. [19] reported a case without any midline venous crossover. Both of these studies postulated this midline crossover as the cause of venous problems. Our own series has identified that there was no midline crossover in 1/16 cadaveric specimens and in 14/100 clinical cases (13 % of cases overall) [3, 4]. A further anatomical factor in the pathogenesis of venous compromise involves the communication between perforating deep veins and the SIEV, as this communication is not uniform, with this communication often of substantially smaller calibre than either the SIEV or the perforating veins themselves. These communications (“oscillating veins” between the adjacent venous territories) [15] may be the limiting factor to venous drainage. The use of preoperative imaging to demonstrate the presence and calibre of these communications may be a useful tool for aiding perforator selection and for maximizing venous outflow [20]. As such, an SIEV greater than 1.5 mm in diameter can be considered a dominant superficial system vein, and a perforating vein greater than 1 mm in diameter is a dominant DIEV perforator.

While planning appropriate venous drainage requires optimization of these anatomical factors in the selection of the best venous perforators, with the SIEV itself able to be used as the primary drainage route, or consideration of using both the DIEV and SIEV in the drainage of a DIEP flap, it is in the secondary situation, after venous congestion has presented, that is the focus of the current manuscript. In this setting, a range of options are on offer for flap salvage, as described earlier. While there is no clear benefit of one technique over another, the ability to harvest a graft rapidly, avoid donor site morbidity, and have substantial length of available graft are the primary objective in all such cases, and the technique described is able to address each of these successfully.

Recall, Sir Harold Gillies’ Principles:
Thou shalt not throw away a living thing.
Thou shalt provide thyself with a lifeboat.
